content: The Act may be cited as the "Carlsbad Irrigation Project Acquired Land Conveyance Act" and includes definitions. The Carlsbad Irrigation Project Acquired Land Conveyance Act defines key terms such as "District" referring to Carlsbad Irrigation District, "Secretary" as the Secretary of the Interior, and "Project" encompassing lands in Eddy County, New Mexico, and related infrastructure. The Carlsbad Irrigation Project Acquired Land Conveyance Act defines key terms and includes the conveyance of the project. The Carlsbad Irrigation Project Acquired Land Conveyance Act involves the conveyance of the Project to the District, with the Secretary retaining title to certain lands under specific dams and reservoir structures. The conveyance must be completed promptly if no changes in Project operations are anticipated. The Secretary must complete the conveyance within 180 days of the enactment of the Act. If changes in Project operations are planned, the conveyance must be done within 2 years. Failure to meet the deadlines will result in the District bearing the full cost of administrative action and environmental compliance. The Secretary must complete the conveyance within 180 days of the enactment of the Act. If changes in Project operations are planned, the conveyance must be done within 2 years. The cost of administrative action and environmental compliance for the conveyance will be borne by the Secretary, with the District responsible for half of the cost if the conveyance is completed before the deadline. SEC. 4. RELATIONSHIP TO EXISTING OPERATIONS. This Act does not significantly change the current use of the Project, which will continue to be managed by the District based on historic operations. Any future alterations must comply with applicable laws. Upon conveyance of the Project under this Act, the District assumes all rights and obligations of the United States under agreements related to the management of lands near Brantley Reservoir for fish and wildlife purposes and Brantley Lake State Park. The District is not obligated for financial support or entitled to any revenues from these agreements. SEC. 6. LEASE MANAGEMENT AND PAST REVENUES COLLECTED FROM THE ACQUIRED LANDS. The Secretary will notify the District of all existing mineral and grazing leases on Project lands and inform leaseholders of the conveyance. The District will take over rights and obligations for these leases, licenses, and permits, and any receipts will be used for Project purposes and Sumner Dam maintenance. The Bureau of Reclamation is responsible for conveyance and major maintenance programs for the Project. Amounts in the reclamation fund will be deposited into the Treasury for deficit reduction. Receipts from mineral and grazing leases on Project lands will be used for Project purposes and Sumner Dam maintenance. The United States will apply up to $200,000 from lands received after the enactment of this Act for costs, with the remainder going to the Treasury for deficit reduction or debt retirement. SEC. 7. WATER CONSERVATION PRACTICES. The District can voluntarily implement water conservation practices. SEC. 8. LIABILITY. The United States will not be liable for damages after the conveyance of the Project. SEC. 9. FUTURE RECLAMATION BENEFITS. The District will not be eligible for emergency loans for maintenance of conveyed facilities.
